response.answer_text: 11 reasons you should buy a smartwatch： 1. Notifications The ease of having them sent to your wrist and being able to identify their importance without removing your phone from a pocket or bag is invaluable. It simplifies your life and it saves time - and time is important. 2. Social etiquette Checking your phone can be rude. Replacing that with a quick glance at your wrist is quicker, simpler and subtler. 3. Internet of Things I can control the volume of my Sonos sound system with a few taps on my wrist, I can also turn Hue lights on and off. Again, it's quicker and simpler than retrieving a phone, and the Internet of Things and 'Smart Home' technology is only set to expand. 4. Travel During Apple's 'Spring Forward' event, Tim Cook demonstrated the Apple Watch being used to get through airport security by displaying the user's boarding pass directly on the watch screen. Anything that makes the airport security process easier is a benefit. 5. Answering calls Various smartwatches handle answering calls differently. The Sony Smartwatch 3, for example, allows users to accept and decline calls on the watch, but activates the phone's speaker and microphone (or headphones, if plugged in) for the conversation. This is helpful when walking around with headphones on, or while driving, when your smartphone isn't easily accessible. Others, such as the Apple Watch, allow users to answer and carry out conversations directly from the watch (the phone may remain in your bag). This may make you feel like Dick Tracy, and it's not the ideal way to answer every call, but it does come in useful for quick conversations when you can't get to you mobile. 6. Fitness I've had a Fitbit, worn it for several weeks, then forgotten about it - it's a common problem with dedicated fitness trackers. All smartwatches are capable of step counting, and most will run fitness apps such as Endomondo and Strava. The benefit of smartwatches is that they hook users in with other useful features, making them less likely to be sidelined. 7. Music You can walk around town listening to music on the phone in your pocket, if a track comes on that you don't like then simply hit 'next' on your smartwatch. You can also pause, adjust the volume or line-up the next track. It's sounds trivial, but it really does make listening to music easier. 8. Battery life One of the biggest drains on your mobile's battery life is that big, high-resolution display - as a smartwatch reduces the amount of time that large screen needs to be on, it can have a significant impact on battery life. And before you question whether being connected to a wearable all-day drains the battery - most use efficient Bluetooth 4.0, which isn't power hungry at all. 9. Customisation Being able to change your watch face everyday is surprisingly fun, on the weekends I can walk around with a dancing Micky Mouse on my wrist, but at the Monday morning office meeting I can wear a more professional watch face. 10. Security Ever found yourself in a rough area at night and too afraid to get your £600 smartphone out? Luckily a smartwatch is a lot more discreet (well, as long as you don't go flashing your £8000 Apple Watch around). 11. Navigation And finally we come to navigation - getting around an unknown city is much easier with a smartwatch. Directions are sent to your wrist, telling you when and where to turn next. Walking around while following directions on your mobile increases the chance of that glass and aluminium baby meeting the cold, hard concrete. Reducing the chance of this happening is another major benefit to wearables. Of course, the main argument against smartwatches is that they simply do everything a smartphone can, which is true, but they're not there to replace your phone - they're there to complement it, and make your life that little bit easier. My answer refers to my experience with my Samsung” S3 Classic” Bluetooth (not LTE) which I have owned for a few weeks. I paid $199 on sale direct from Samsung, less $25 I had in Samsung points from using the Samsung Pay credit card app on my phone. I only purchased it after seeing how well my son’s Frontier S3 model functioned for him. The S3 has MST (magnetic swipe technology) and can make contactless payments on credit card terminals that only accept magnetic swipes as well as the newer terminals that use contactless NFC. I make easy credit card transactions using Samsung Pay app on nearly any credit card terminal. The newer Samsung “Galaxy” smartwatch does not have MST technology and requires a terminal with NFC when using the Samsung Pay app. I have been using Samsung Pay on my Samsung Galaxy S7 phone for nearly two years and love it. Many retailers and merchants have yet to upgrade to accept contactless payments but the S3 works on most (all?) of these older systems that require a card swipe. I frequently have cashiers tell me when they notice me holding my phone (and now smartwatch) near the terminal that it won’t work on their system only to be surprised when the transaction is processed. The S3 smartwatch is faster and easier than using my phone. The app uses tokens or a virtual number instead of the actual credit card number, so provides an extra level of security. I can use my voice to initiate texts and phone calls directly on the watch while my phone remains in my pocket. This is especially helpful during the colder months when I am wearing jackets with lots of my phone is buried in an inside pocket. I have missed many calls while trying to get my phone out. Or if I left my phone in my jacket or downstairs etc. I still have my watch on to receive calls and notifications. Also when driving I can use the watch to text, which is disabled in my (current) car’s system unless I am stopped. (I only do short quick texts while driving). It can all be done via the S Voice app without having to touch the screen. I have had to adjust the name of a few contacts as the voice recognition did not always recognize or distinguish certain similar sounding names. There are some 3rd party apps that can be installed to allow the watch to better manage notifications. Samsung’s “S Voice” works but can be slow depending on what you need to do. Asking to navigate to a destination will take longer than a less complex request like “call…” a contact. Perhaps if you download the map base to your phone it would be faster but I have not wanted to bother installing the map base. These little smartwatches do not have the processing power of a modern smartphone and should not be expected to perform at the same levels. They may also be transferring data from the phone. The texting and phone dialing has worked well for me. I have not found a situation where I would have wanted to use it for navigation. I can quickly see notifications and reply, mark as “read” or delete without pulling out my phone. I can easily see the weather either by a single swipe of the screen, using the S Voice function ,widget or from a link built in to certain watch faces. Yes the phone has it bit this is another example of something that is just easier on the watch. I am doing much better at keeping track of my heart rate and steps since the watch is always on my wrist. Often I would not be carrying my phone if at home or work etc. The info syncs with the Samsung Health app on my phone. The “Find my phone”app” has proven a great convenience too. I use it nearly daily! There are many watch faces available. I have installed about 30 free ones. Some even have built in shortcuts to apps like Calendar, weather, health, timer etc. Most I have installed display both 12 and 24 hour times as well as battery, steps, heart rate, day and date. This Samsung watch is easy to charge and uses a wireless charging dock with a built in magnet to hold the watch in place. No need t plug in a tiny USB plug. I have replaced the watch band with one with a deployment clasp making it easy to take off and charge at night. I found the leather one supplied to be a bit stiff and cumbersome. I have not had any reason to use the GPS capability as I would typically just use my phone’s Google or car’s systems. There is a built in SOS feature that will send and track your location to phone numbers that you have pre-programmed. Pressing the “Home” button 3 times will activate the SOS. There is no builtin native navigation but there are apps available to install. I installed “Here WeGo” a free navigation app that is recommended by some. It seemed to work well but I don’t believe it is a replacement for my Google Maps or car”s GPS system. I installed a calculator app that comes in handy for calculating tips or tax without being obvious. Also a flashlight app turns the screen in to a light that helps read menus in dark restaurants. I use the timer, opening and setting by voice. You can set a custom prompt to open the S Voice dialogue. I set it to open with “engage voice function”. The link to a timer on a watchface I installed did not open a timer. I failed to realize the watch does not have a native timer app. I only had to install a timer app though the Samsung Gear app. Same with the stop watch app. All is good now! There is a music player but I still use my phone for music. A complaint many have is the lack of apps compared to the Android Wear OS watches. I have not found this to be an issue as there are enough to make the device very convenient and useful. There is nothing you can’t do with a smartphone but the watch makes certain things much easier for me but it will depend on individual needs and habits. Another complaint is the battery life which Samsung can claim to be up to 4 days but most seem to get 2 days, as seems to be my experience. It is not a problem for me since I charge overnight just as I do with my phone. It is possible to put it in watch only mode which can extend the battery for a few weeks Samsung says. I am aware some smartwatches have longer battery life but it is not a big deal for me. I am use to charging nightly. I have to admit I had been skeptical but have found it has made life easier and I would not want to be without it.

I have a Seiko 5 that made in February 1969. Has a day/date complication. It’s still working and is accurate to within 15 seconds per day, usually within 10 seconds. Ought to take it in and have it serviced with cleaning and relube after 51 years, but a timegrapher shows it’s still got decent balance wheel amplitude, and its beat is steady. Not a high priority. I’ve got a few others over 45 years old that need to be cleaned and serviced more than it does. By comparison, a “smartwatch” will be obsolete in about two and certainly within three years. In the era of 1970 mechanical watches, one that was only good for a couple of years was considered a throwaway - much like a zero jewel pin lever escapement watch with a chrome plated “base metal” case you could buy for a dollar or two at Kmart. If it died after a couple years, you pitched it and bought another. They were considered “beaters” by miners, heavy equipment mechanics, millwrights, oil drillers, military and others who tended to bash and thrash watches to death very quickly on the job. That was the same era of $1.25/hour minimum wage. If it lasted even six months, the price was right for a throwaway beater. Now consider the price of a smartwatch and amortize that across two and three years, its technological lifespan. Doesn’t matter if it still powers up or not, or recharges or not. It’s technologically obsolete and won’t “connect” with anything, making it worthless. Welcome to “programmed obsolescence” in which consumer electronics manufacturers deliberately make the electronics they sell you worthless within several years. Buy an Apple Watch for $300 and it amortizes to $100-$150 per year of useful service - and that’s a lower priced one. Up it to the $450 model and it’s $150-$225 per year. For that much I expect it to wash the windows and launder my clothes. I see all the gizmo stuff they allegedly do and am truly amazed how I managed to survive the 1960’s, 1970’s, 1980’s and 1990’s without any of it. Cute, but adds nothing of any real, tangible, value to my life . . . and it certainly would not saving me any time. The cost-benefit ratio is appallingly abysmal. Yet one more fancy gizmo to get money from your pocket to theirs . . . in large quantity every two years.

Are smartwatches worth buying or am I better off with a durable plain watch? A smartwatch is as durable/longterm as a mobile phone. This is the sad truth. As they are objects bound to technology, they are going to be superseded by other devices as time goes by. So, eventually your smartwatch in a few years will become a memento of times gone. Maybe worth to someone as a curio, but definitely not something you are going to wear each day every day. I could be wrong, of course - I do not have a scrying ball where I can see into the future - but it has happened like this is almost every niche connected to the technology field. I will make you an example of what happened to me. As for myself, I remember buying a notepad-cum-GPS, something like 10/15 years ago. Boy, what a useless piece of junk it was! It drew enormous battery juice - like having a four to six hours reserve before charging. If you used the GPS intensively, the reserve of power was severely reduced. And the worst part is that it cost a small fortune. I used it until the thrill of the new gizmo faded, wounded by its obvious technical issues, and quietly the device found its resting place in a drawer, until I threw it away when its batteries leaked and rendered it useless for good. If I had spent that money on a good watch (and I could have bought a somewhat nice one - possibly in the 1.500/2.000 USD range when new - I would have used it for all this time without it losing value and eventually ending up in the trash bin. Now that I think about it, it has been one of the worst buying decisions in all my life. So, my educated advice is to think twice before spending your money. I do not want to deter you from buying a smartwatch, but I urge you to spend as little as you can on something that will become obsolete soon. There are some nice watches which do not cost a fortune, so you would be good buying one of those, knowing beforehand that it is a - ehm - disposable device that will probably end up in a drawer sooner or later. If you want to buy a smartwatch, one that I could consider right now is the Skagen Connected, at about USD 150 (limited set of interaction with this, as it is an analogic display one), or the Skagen Falster, at USD 250, if you really want to splurge and want a true lcd device on your wrist. I like their style - even if I know for sure that Skagen, since its buying by the Fossil Group, has lowered its standards of quality, unfortunately. I have always had a strange passion for Skagen, even if I know very well that they are cheaply made watches - but hey, just bear with me. So, my friend, your choice. But if I had to spend my money somewhere, I would first of all buy a good watch (most possibly, a nice second-wrist watch), and a smartwatch (eventually) with what is left of that money. And if you plan carefully, you may just do that: a simple, good second-wrist mechanical from the sicties would cost you around 200 USD. With the Skagen, you would add other 150 USD. The total of 350 USD would buy you a new Apple Watch. Thanks for the A2A…..I purchased an iWatch….I have all Apple products so everything syncs……That said, I didn’t need a watch, and I didn’t buy one because it was the “thing to do”….and “everybody has one’…syndrome….. My husband is a stroke victim…he was left with very limited mobility and almost no speech or means of communication. He is on the same level as a toddler, unable to read, write or even turn on the TV. Knowing that I had to change a lot of the things I had previously taken for granted…. I have a programable wall phone that no matter what number you push, it automatically goes to 911. That was the only means of instant help I had in the beginning…. When I heard the iWatch had a GPS and a one button 911 feature, I knew I needed that. Although a cell phone does the same, locating it when things get chaotic is a feat in itself. Cell phones can be anywhere and when you are trying to focus on the immediate problem, good luck with that. That was my reason for the purchase. He needs help, it’s always with me on my wrist, no searching, it’s there. And keep in mind, chaos can happen while driving far from home…..so those “help I can’t get up” devises are still a part-time help, and he would not understand what to do with it anyway. I needed something for me, and the IWatch solved the problem. Now after having had it for a while….I can’t imagine how I got along without it. It does everything my other Apple products do. I won't go into details, but it’s the most comforting experience you can have. If staying on top of everything “energizes”you, then a smartwatch is for you.

IMHO, No. And my reasons are two-fold: a) A smartwatch is first and foremost - A watch. And regular watches last a lot longer on a single battery than a smart watch does in a single charge. b) I am more or less going to refer to my phone for more detailed information about a particular notification - Frustratingly owing to the fact that I would’ve disabled functionality on my smartwatch to eke out more battery life to serve (a). When the Moto 360 came out in 2014, I was an early adopter (and my G-Shock had just exhausted its battery) ,wanting to try out this fancy new gadget that offered immediate notifications without having to look at my phone. I was able to : Read my emails.Attend calls.Navigate through Google Maps.Change songs through Spotify / SoundCloud.Add reminders and use Google Now in general.Reply to Skype / WhatsApp messages.I was even able to opt from a slew of watch faces which was super-cool!Every night, I would place the watch in it’s charging dock and it would charge within 45 minutes. This is what eventually wore down the smart watch for me. Yes, I know the 1st Gen Moto 360 was never going to have awesome battery life but I want one less device (apart from my two phones, my laptop) to worry about as far as charging is concerned. For comparison, my G-Shock lasted 7 years before the battery died. Besides, once my work emails started appearing on my phone, my watch died in half day because of the amount of notifications that popped out. I was running more or less in Airplane mode just to conserve battery…. which defeated the purpose of a smartwatch. In the end, I have my trusted Seiko Solar Chronograph and a Citizen Navihawk running on Light energy. They may not show me my notifications… but I will never run out of battery on these devices.

In the modern era, we are often encapsulated by technology. After all, in the past thirty years it has progressed so rapidly that it is hard to keep track of what was developed when. When something new and gadget-y comes out, it is hard for us to resist forking out the cash to try it out for ourselves and be part of the latest craze. This is just as true for the smart watch as it is for regular tech. However, are smart watches really worth the money? Is the traditional watch perhaps the best way to go? In this article, we take a look and see which one is really on top.  The Smart Watch: Pros and Cons There are some great advantages to a , and one of these is the fact that you have everything in one easy to access place. You can call your friends, respond to text messages, take photographs, check events, receive phone calls, and so much more. There is a huge list of features that are easy for you to reach. You can even pay for purchases on your card with them. They look good as well, nothing says stylish more than a fancy new smart watch on your arm. Plus, it syncs nicely with your phone and computer, so you can access everything all the time. However, there are a few disadvantages to smart watches as well. One of these is the fact that they are very expensive, with the entry level models starting at around £300. They can break easily, and the cost of repair is often the same as the purchase price. Plus, it can be hard to tell the time and you end up having to flick your arm in a most dramatic manner. They can also be fiddly to use and the novelty soon wears off. They are fun to play with, and can be useful to some people, but for the majority they end up a novelty. The Traditional Watch: Pros and Cons There are some advantages to the traditional watch. It can be simple or complex, but without the latest technology installed. They are much more varied and come in a variety of styles and with a wide range of price tags. It is easy to tell the time with them, and some will be able to tell you the date and even the current weather, but without the need for expensive technology. It doesn't have bugs, it doesn't need to be restarted when encountering an error (as there are none), and there are no frustrating synch issues. They are made with care and precision; you can feel the passion the watchmaker had when constructing each piece. In an ever advancing world, it brings you back a little. Of course, there are a couple of disadvantages too. They don't offer the same level of functionality as a smart watch, although for those who are looking to take a step back from tech, this is not all bad. The nicest ones are also often the most expensive, which can be a shame when you go to buy a traditional watch. Resource Link: Great Selection, Wooden, Mechanical and Quartz

As a Mac developer, I think the Apple Watch is beyond hideous, it’s so awful to behold that it discredits design by calling it “awful design”, I think it’s better just to say it wasn’t designed, and save offending anyone. Battery life makes it of limited use, say if go for a weekend away, it’s another charger to pack, whereas an automatic watch charges from the movement of the wrist. An Apple Watch does much more of course, but it duplicates functionality found on my phone, so I don’t want to have the Apple Watch with me any more than I want a second phone with me. Unlike my Deep Blue watch, it’s not waterproof, so it’s doesn’t present usefulness as a sports watch, to me. Worst of all perhaps, most of us are only prepared to wear one watch at a time, so it’s taking a spot on my wrist which could be better used by something not so grotesque. I think a smartwatch is a solution in search of a problem, and solves the imaginary problem with the ugliest watch I’ve ever seen. At least the $50 Android devices are honest about being cheap, the Apple Watch is priced expensively, but cheap, in, well, spirit. It might not be cheap like a $5 pizza, but it’s cheap like a bribed police officer. Smartwatches represent the nadir of innovation in this computer industry.

A smart watch is probably most aptly described by Wikipedia as “a computerized wristwatch with functionality that goes beyond timekeeping”. While the concept has been toyed with since the 70s, it is only in the past few years that it got a huge push. Pebble, one of the most successful Kickstarter projects at the time, got the ball rolling in 2012 with Google and Apple following two years later. But in 2017 it’s safe (and a bit sad) to say that the smartwatch buzz has died down. Pebble got sold to Fitbit amid financial troubles. Google’s Android Wear watches have largely flopped with some manufacturers walking away from the platform. Apple with all its marketing and retail push won’t reveal it’s Watch sales figures — maybe because they’re not boast-worthy like their other product lines.

Not worth if you already have a smartphone. Sure, it’s nice that you can do things that smartphones do without having to take your phone from the pocket, but do you really want to spend that much money for this unnecessary convenience ? A durable watch like G-Shock can last for decades. My 8-year old G-Shock’s battery is still working since I bought it.
